title: The segment that was TOO SHOCKING for The Kyle and Jackie O Show
text:
They're the controversial radio duo known to push the boundaries of good taste.

And this week, Kyle Sandilands and Jackie 'O' Henderson revealed a list of segments that were too outrageous to put on the air.

'Let's go through some ideas that never made it to air,' Jackie told listeners. 'These ideas were too ridiculous, they were dumb or illegal.'

The segment that was too shocking for The Kyle and Jackie O Show: The KIIS FM radio hosts (pictured) have revealed the 'dumb and illegal' prank they once tried to pull on their staff

Perhaps the most shocking segment involved Jackie testing the loyalty of KIIS FM staff members by calling them up at 1am and asking for their help getting rid of a dead body.

If they agreed to help, no questions asked, then they would pass the 'loyalty test'.

Another segment that didn't make the cut involved listeners coming into the studio to see who could fart the loudest using a sound level meter.

Apparently, Kyle didn't want to do the segment because it was 'too childish'.

Too extreme? Perhaps the most tasteless segment that didn't make it to air involved Jackie (pictured) testing the loyalty of KIIS FM staff members by calling them up at 1am and asking for their help getting rid of a dead body

Another axed segment, called 'The Poo-jitive', involved listeners running around Sydney looking for mystery 'poopers' hiding in bathroom stalls across the city.

Contestants would have to knock on the right door and ask, 'Are you the poo-jitive?'

Kyle revealed they also had the idea of recording an entire episode of The Kyle and Jackie O Show using sign language for deaf listeners.

Tone dead? Kyle (pictured) revealed they also had the idea of recording an entire episode of The Kyle and Jackie O Show using sign language for deaf listeners

The broadcast would have been streamed online for people to watch.

The plan didn't work out, however, because neither Kyle nor Jackie knows sign language.

'Our entire radio show would be performed in silence. Yeah, we can’t see that working too well...' Kyle said.
description: They're the controversial radio duo known to push the boundaries of good taste.
authors: Ali Daher For Daily Mail Australia
